GENERAL. A further decline in industrial activity has taken place in the week ended the 4th February. Short-time is increasing, and apprehension is felt in several industries that the continued absence of orders will shortly mean a further extension of short- time working. This relates especially to the cotton industry, where anticipated ......----------------........ - i.................................... - 1 demands have failed to mature. Some improvement is manifested in the boot and shoe industry, and longer hours are being worked, more particularly among firms engaged in a medium-class trade. Improvement is also taking place in the lace industry, and some additional orders have been received by hosiery firms. The position in the jute trade appears to be firmer, and the statement that no further reduction in prices can be made is expected to have a steadying effect upon the market. In spite of the fall in prices, the position in the iron and steel trade remains abnormal. Short-time working is becoming more common in the cutlery and gold and silver trades. The joiners' strike in connection with the shipbuilding industry continues, and no improvement can be expected until this dispute is settled. The position with regard to shiprepairing has, however, somewhat improved in South WaTeFand at Avonmouth. II. EMERGENCY WORK. The Prime Minister made a statement in the House of Commons on the 19th October on the proposals of the Government to provide against unemployment. He outlined schemes for employing a large number of fit ex-Service men in connection with the Housing Programme, on which negotiations with the trade unions were proceeding; and schemes for anticipating a four years' programme for Arterial Roads in London and in the provinces; whilst at the same time pressing forward with the Ministry of Transports programme of road classification and maintenance grants. A further statement was made by the Minister of Labour on the 21st December, indicating that the further proposals of the Government included: a final endeavour to secure an agreement with the building trades for the admission of ex-Service men; a rapid extension of road construction schemes; the distribution by the Unemploy- ment Grants Committee, under the Chairmanship of Viscount St. Davids, of a sum of 3,000,000 for the purpose of assisting local authorities on relief schemes other than house building and road work; and the amendment of the Unemployment Insurance Act (1920) in order to enable benefit to be paid to workpeople who had been unemployed since the Act came into operation and could not therefore qualify for benefit. It has since been agreed that the Unemployment Grants Committee shall also deal with schemes in respect of road work other than those undertaken by theMinistry of Transport. ROAD WORK PROGRAMME. (Information supplied by the Ministry of Transport.) (1.) LONDON ARTERIAL NEW ROADS. No fresh Arterial Road Schemes in the London area have been notified by theMinistry of Transport since those mentioned in Report No. 15. There are now nineteen Arterial Road Schemes in the greater London area.Work has commenced on thirteen of these schemes and the number of men employedon the 4th February was 922. ALTERNATIVE WORK AT WAR DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHMENTS. A return rendered by the War Office in respect of the week ended the 29thJanuary shows that alternative work was in progress at five national factories, and included waggon repairing, manufacture of medals, coin blanks, locomotives andnew waggons and miscellaneous articles for the Post Office and for private firms. Alternative work has also been adopted at His Majesty's Dockyards and otherAdmiralty Industrial Establishments. [Total number of workmen employed on alternative workatt War OfficeEstablishments ^ 2,630. ] [Total number of workmen employed on alternative work at AdmiraltyEstablishments ^5,621. j (6.) VISCOUNT ST. DAVIDS' COMMITTEE. In accordance with the announcement in the House of Commons on the 21stDecember, an Unemployment Grants Committee has been appointed under theChairmanship of Viscount St. Davids to administer a grant of 3,000,000 which hadbeen allocated for the purpose of assisting Local Authorities in carrying out approved schemes of useful work other than roads and housing. The restriction in regardto road work has since been removed. Works are approved only in areas where serious unemployment exists which isnot otherwise provided for. Preference in employment is given to ex-Service men.Grants do not exceed 60 per cent, of the wages bill of additional unemployed men engaged, and the works undertaken are such as are approved by the appropriateGovernment Departments as suitable works of public utility. Up to the 4th February seventy-nine applications for grants had been sanctionedin respect of sixty-five Local Authorities. The total sum allocated under thesesanctions was 431,107. Returns from fifty-three Local Authorities in the greater London area and 115Local Authorities in the provinces show that the labour at present engaged onschemes towards which a grant has been made is as follows: (a.) SHORT-TIME IN GOVERNMENT ESTABLISHMENTS. The '' short-time '' system came into force on the 24th January, and took effecton that date in His Majesty's Dockyards and Admiralty Establishments and in theRoyal Ordnance Factories, Woolwich Arsenal, and National Factories administered by the War Office. It will be introduced, where practicable, in all remaining WarDepartments, Industrial and Semi-Industrial Establishments with effect from the7th February. For the week, commencing the 31st January, the number of additional men engaged under the " short-time " scheme at War Office Departments was 1,417. The number engaged at His Majesty's Doqkyards and. other Admiralty andIndustrial Establishments on the 29th January was 3,429.
